articles.headline: You Don’t Need to Go to the Dark Web to Find Hateful Conspiracy Theories
articles.snippet: Major publishers, media companies and theater chains are also in the business of poisoning the discourse.
articles.abstract: Major publishers, media companies and theater chains are also in the business of poisoning the discourse.
articles.lead_paragraph: You don’t have to go deep into the internet to find the baseless conspiracies that provided a backdrop for mass murder in Pittsburgh and the recent pipe-bomb mailings to Barack Obama, the Clintons, George Soros and CNN. They are served up in plain sight, for profit, at airport bookstores, at movie-theater chains and on cable television.

articles.headline: In U.S.-India Trade, Trump Sees Only Harley-Davidson
articles.snippet: India and the United States face deadlines in the coming days to decide disputes over trade and oil. The president is most interested in motorcycle tariffs.
articles.abstract: India and the United States face deadlines in the coming days to decide disputes over trade and oil. The president is most interested in motorcycle tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When it comes to trade, it often seems that India and the United States are playing a perplexing game of multidimensional chess.

articles.headline: How Mark Zuckerberg Became Too Big to Fail
articles.snippet: Facebook has had a turbulent two years. But almost no one in tech thinks Mr. Zuckerberg, the social network’s chief executive, should step down from the company he built.
articles.abstract: Facebook has had a turbulent two years. But almost no one in tech thinks Mr. Zuckerberg, the social network’s chief executive, should step down from the company he built.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, after Facebook revealed that tens of millions of its users’ accounts had been exposed in a security breach, I began asking people in and around the tech industry a simple question: Should Mark Zuckerberg still be running Facebook?

articles.headline: 2 Views of Angela Merkel’s Legacy: Stoic Leadership, and Economic Malpractice
articles.snippet: The exiting German chancellor is celebrated as a rare source of European leadership. But many economists blame her for austerity that inflamed populism.
articles.abstract: The exiting German chancellor is celebrated as a rare source of European leadership. But many economists blame her for austerity that inflamed populism.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the political obituaries chronicling the departure of Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, the world is preparing to lose a rare source of sober-minded leadership at a time rife with dangerous tumult.

articles.headline: It’s Obamacare Sign-Up Time: How to Untangle Coverage Choices
articles.snippet: The insurance marketplace created by the Affordable Care Act is still here, but Republican efforts to hobble the law have yielded new options, and some potential pitfalls, now that open enrollment has begun.
articles.abstract: The insurance marketplace created by the Affordable Care Act is still here, but Republican efforts to hobble the law have yielded new options, and some potential pitfalls, now that open enrollment has begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite efforts by President Trump and congressional Republicans to hobble the Affordable Care Act, the health insurance marketplace it created is still standing.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Ensnarled in Vast 1MDB Fraud Scandal
articles.snippet: The filing of federal charges could increase pressure on Goldman, the primary bond underwriter for the development fund at the center of the so-called 1MDB scandal.
articles.abstract: The filing of federal charges could increase pressure on Goldman, the primary bond underwriter for the development fund at the center of the so-called 1MDB scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is facing one of the most significant scandals in its history, a multibillion-dollar international fraud that investigators say was masterminded by a flamboyant financier with a taste for Hollywood and carried out with help from the Wall Street firm’s bankers.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Alexandra Stevenson and Emily Flitter
